articles.headline: As VW Pleads Guilty in U.S. Over Diesel Scandal, Trouble Looms in Europe
articles.snippet: Even as it moved to end legal action in the United States over its efforts to illegally evade emissions standards, the German carmaker faces mounting legal woes in Europe.
articles.abstract: Even as it moved to end legal action in the United States over its efforts to illegally evade emissions standards, the German carmaker faces mounting legal woes in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen took a big step toward resolving its legal problems in the United States when it pleaded guilty on Friday to its vast emissions deception. But in Europe, its troubles may be just beginning.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Honey, Please Pick Up Some Grilled Tilapia at the Gas Station
articles.snippet: A wave of gas stations and convenience stores are capitalizing on a growing demand for fresh, healthful and convenient road food.
articles.abstract: A wave of gas stations and convenience stores are capitalizing on a growing demand for fresh, healthful and convenient road food.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Va. — Last summer, when two women were looking for a restaurant space in this Northern Virginia town of 48,000, one of the options held multiple enticements: It was affordable, it had a good location, the kitchen was fit for Asian cooking and it was in a gas station.

articles.headline: Kids Are Getting Older Quicker. And Disney Tries to Adapt.
articles.snippet: With “Andi Mack,” a comedic drama that’s bitter and sweet, Disney Channel stretches its brand. It’s part of an effort to lift sinking ratings.
articles.abstract: With “Andi Mack,” a comedic drama that’s bitter and sweet, Disney Channel stretches its brand. It’s part of an effort to lift sinking ratings.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Grandma is mad. Her grown daughter, Bex, who got pregnant as a teenager, just blazed back into town and let a big secret slip. Grandma had raised 13-year-old Andi to believe that Bex was her older sister. Well, the truth is a tad more complicated.

articles.headline: Trump’s Plan on Fannie and Freddie? Clues May Emerge Soon
articles.snippet: In coming weeks, the new administration will decide whether to keep the mortgage giants under federal supervision — and continue reaping their profits.
articles.abstract: In coming weeks, the new administration will decide whether to keep the mortgage giants under federal supervision — and continue reaping their profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fixing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance giants that still operate under government supervision, is nowhere near the top of the Trump administration’s to-do list. Since the election, administration officials, including Steven T. Mnuchin, the United States Treasury secretary, have said little about their plans for the companies.

articles.headline: Michael Flynn Was Paid to Represent Turkey’s Interests During Trump Campaign
articles.snippet: President Trump’s first national security adviser, who resigned after less than a month, accepted over $500,000 to investigate a Turkish cleric in Pennsylvania.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s first national security adviser, who resigned after less than a month, accepted over $500,000 to investigate a Turkish cleric in Pennsylvania.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The candidate he was advising last fall was running on a platform of America First. The client he was working for last fall was paying him more than $500,000 to put Turkey first.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Ouster of South Korean President Could Return Liberals to Power
articles.snippet: The opposition leader, who could become the next president, wants dialogue with North Korea and is skeptical about the new American antimissile shield.
articles.abstract: The opposition leader, who could become the next president, wants dialogue with North Korea and is skeptical about the new American antimissile shield.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The foes of South Korea’s likely new leaders have called them blindly naïve, closet North Korea followers and anti-American — an unsettling accusation in a country where the alliance with Washington has been the military bedrock for seven decades.

articles.headline: Trump Abruptly Orders 46 Obama-Era Prosecutors to Resign
articles.snippet: The president told the holdover United States attorneys to tender their resignations immediately, including — surprisingly — Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan.
articles.abstract: The president told the holdover United States attorneys to tender their resignations immediately, including — surprisingly — Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration moved on Friday to sweep away most of the remaining vestiges of Obama administration prosecutors at the Justice Department, ordering 46 holdover United States attorneys to tender their resignations immediately — including Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: S.E.C. Rejects Winklevoss Brothers’ Bid to Create Bitcoin E.T.F.
articles.snippet: The price of Bitcoin tumbled after the Securities and Exchange Commission rejected the brothers’ application for an exchange-traded fund.
articles.abstract: The price of Bitcoin tumbled after the Securities and Exchange Commission rejected the brothers’ application for an exchange-traded fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Friday it had rejected an application to create an exchange-traded fund tied to the price of Bitcoin.

articles.headline: Behind the Quiet State-by-State Fight Over Electric Vehicles
articles.snippet: While the battle in Washington gets much of the attention, the most direct attack against electric vehicles is being waged in statehouses.
articles.abstract: While the battle in Washington gets much of the attention, the most direct attack against electric vehicles is being waged in statehouses.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Georgia repealed its generous $5,000 tax credit on electric vehicles in July 2015, and instead slapped a $200 registration fee on electric cars, sales quickly tumbled.

articles.headline: The G.O.P.’s High-Risk Strategy for Health Law Repeal
articles.snippet: The party’s plan to toss out the Affordable Care Act could cause turmoil in the insurance market next year, and for Republicans themselves in the 2018 midterm elections.
articles.abstract: The party’s plan to toss out the Affordable Care Act could cause turmoil in the insurance market next year, and for Republicans themselves in the 2018 midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump and House Republicans are pressing forward with a high-risk strategy to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act, disregarding the views of medical professionals and potentially imperiling the party’s political future in conservative states where many voters stand to lose their health care.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Meet Diego, the Centenarian Whose Sex Drive Saved His Species
articles.snippet: By fathering hundreds, a giant tortoise in the Galápagos Islands reversed the threat of extinction. Another, earning the name Lonesome George, was unable to do the same.
articles.abstract: By fathering hundreds, a giant tortoise in the Galápagos Islands reversed the threat of extinction. Another, earning the name Lonesome George, was unable to do the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLES DARWIN RESEARCH STATION, Galápagos — Of all the giant tortoises on these islands, where the theory of evolution was born, only a few have received names that stuck.

articles.headline: Tillerson Leads From State Dept. Shadows as White House Steps In
articles.snippet: In the Washington of President Trump, Rex W. Tillerson has taken an understated approach that can be seen as brilliant, mystifying or a prescription for powerlessness.
articles.abstract: In the Washington of President Trump, Rex W. Tillerson has taken an understated approach that can be seen as brilliant, mystifying or a prescription for powerlessness.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Henry A. Kissinger slipped into the State Department last week for a quiet lunch in his old office with Rex W. Tillerson, the former Exxon Mobil chief executive, who has all but covered himself in a cloak of invisibility in his first six weeks as secretary of state.

articles.headline: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara Says He Was Fired After Refusing to Quit
articles.snippet: The Manhattan federal prosecutor was among 46 United States attorneys who had been ordered to submit their resignations.
articles.abstract: The Manhattan federal prosecutor was among 46 United States attorneys who had been ordered to submit their resignations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The call to Preet Bharara’s office from President Trump’s assistant came on Thursday. Would Mr. Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, please call back?
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Putin and Merkel: A Rivalry of History, Distrust and Power
articles.snippet: Vladimir Putin and Angela Merkel now represent the sharply divergent visions clashing in the world. The question is, which one will come out on top?
articles.abstract: Vladimir Putin and Angela Merkel now represent the sharply divergent visions clashing in the world. The question is, which one will come out on top?
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — He was skinny in his trim, dark suit, an almost lupine figure, nervous and unexpectedly youthful for a president of Russia. Taking the lectern beneath the dome of the restored Reichstag, Vladimir V. Putin soon shifted to German, with a fluency that startled the German lawmakers and a pro-West message that reassured them. The Cold War seemed over.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: Russian Espionage Piggybacks on a Cybercriminal’s Hacking
articles.snippet: It appears that the Russian authorities, leaning on the work of a hacker, grafted an intelligence operation onto a far-reaching cybercriminal scheme.
articles.abstract: It appears that the Russian authorities, leaning on the work of a hacker, grafted an intelligence operation onto a far-reaching cybercriminal scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the F.B.I., Evgeniy M. Bogachev is the most wanted cybercriminal in the world. The bureau has announced a $3 million bounty for his capture, the most ever for computer crimes, and has been trying to track his movements in hopes of grabbing him if he strays outside his home turf in Russia.
articles.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Joseph Goldstein

articles.headline: After $225 Billion in Deals Last Year, China Reins In Overseas Investment
articles.snippet: Chinese officials are warning that they will crack down on “blind and irrational” acquisitions amid rising worries about money leaving the country.
articles.abstract: Chinese officials are warning that they will crack down on “blind and irrational” acquisitions amid rising worries about money leaving the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China struck $225 billion in deals to acquire companies abroad last year, a record-breaking number that signaled to the world that Chinese business leaders were hot to haggle.

articles.headline: 2 of a Farmer’s 3 Children Overdosed. What of the Third — and the Land?
articles.snippet: Opioid addiction is ravaging America’s farmland, tearing at communities and posing a new threat to families that have worked the same soil for generations.
articles.abstract: Opioid addiction is ravaging America’s farmland, tearing at communities and posing a new threat to families that have worked the same soil for generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: BLANCHESTER, Ohio — A life of farming taught Roger Winemiller plenty about harsh twists of fate: hailstorms and drought, ragweed infestations and jittery crop prices. He hadn’t bargained on heroin.

articles.headline: Trump Lets Key Offices Gather Dust Amid ‘Slowest Transition in Decades’
articles.snippet: The president is months behind where experts in both parties, even some inside his administration, say he should be in filling senior government positions.
articles.abstract: The president is months behind where experts in both parties, even some inside his administration, say he should be in filling senior government positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the State Department, the normally pulsating hub of executive offices is hushed and virtually empty. At the Pentagon, military missions in some of the world’s most troubled places are being run by a defense secretary who has none of his top team in place. And at departments like Treasury, Commerce and Health and Human Services, many senior posts remain vacant even as the agencies have been handed enormous tasks like remaking the nation’s health insurance system.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Trump Wants Faster Growth. The Fed Isn’t So Sure.
articles.snippet: The president has called for speeding up growth, but the central bank estimates that the economy is already growing at something like the maximum sustainable pace.
articles.abstract: The president has called for speeding up growth, but the central bank estimates that the economy is already growing at something like the maximum sustainable pace.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For President Trump and his economic advisers, the strong February jobs report was a cause for celebration — and a first step toward delivering on the president’s promise of faster economic growth.

articles.headline: The President Changed. So Has Small Businesses’ Confidence.
articles.snippet: Executives in Toledo, Ohio, say their prospects are better under President Trump, citing his promises of fewer regulations and lower taxes and health care costs.
articles.abstract: Executives in Toledo, Ohio, say their prospects are better under President Trump, citing his promises of fewer regulations and lower taxes and health care costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOLEDO, Ohio — The cream of the small-business community here tucked into their lunch on a top floor of a bank building and pondered the question put to them by their local lender’s economist.

articles.headline: For Solace and Solidarity in the Trump Age, Liberals Turn the TV Back On
articles.snippet: The turbocharged ratings are a surprise even to seen-it-all executives who had been bracing for a plunge in viewership after the excitement of the election.
articles.abstract: The turbocharged ratings are a surprise even to seen-it-all executives who had been bracing for a plunge in viewership after the excitement of the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is a new safe space for liberals in the age of President Trump: the television set.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin

articles.headline: Miscue Calls Attention to Amazon’s Dominance in Cloud Computing
articles.snippet: A rare service breakdown has provided an opportunity for rivals like Google and Microsoft to preach the benefits of working with multiple providers.
articles.abstract: A rare service breakdown has provided an opportunity for rivals like Google and Microsoft to preach the benefits of working with multiple providers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — There have been many opportunities to consider how crucial Amazon has become to the smooth operation of the internet over the past few years.

articles.headline: The Choose-Your-Own-News Adventure
articles.snippet: In a time of highly personalized feeds, competing narratives vie for supremacy in debates that should be indisputable, our media columnist writes.
articles.abstract: In a time of highly personalized feeds, competing narratives vie for supremacy in debates that should be indisputable, our media columnist writes.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — A fascinating story emerged about Netflix last week.

articles.headline: Netherlands Considers a New Relationship to Muslims With Coming Election
articles.snippet: This week’s elections in the Netherlands will begin Europe’s year of political reckoning, as countries contend with waves of populism and anti-Muslim sentiment.
articles.abstract: This week’s elections in the Netherlands will begin Europe’s year of political reckoning, as countries contend with waves of populism and anti-Muslim sentiment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands — Like many Muslims, Ahmed Aboutaleb has been disturbed by the angry tenor of the Dutch election campaign. Far-right candidates have disparaged Islam, often depicting Muslims as outsiders unwilling to integrate into Dutch culture.

articles.headline: When a Common Sedative Becomes an Execution Drug
articles.snippet: Midazolam, one of the most widely used sedatives, has become central in recent years to the debate about capital punishment in the United States.
articles.abstract: Midazolam, one of the most widely used sedatives, has become central in recent years to the debate about capital punishment in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — When a chemist named Armin Walser helped invent a sedative more powerful than Valium more than 40 years ago, he thought his team’s concoction was meant to make people’s lives easier, not their deaths.

articles.headline: Intel Buys Mobileye in $15.3 Billion Bid to Lead Self-Driving Car Market
articles.snippet: The deal underlines the chip maker’s determination to make sure it can provide the computing power needed for autonomous vehicles.
articles.abstract: The deal underlines the chip maker’s determination to make sure it can provide the computing power needed for autonomous vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world of driverless cars, household names like Google and Uber have raced ahead of rivals, building test vehicles and starting trials on city streets.
